Ok so this had me confused for a while, but I think I finally got it!

So basically try to picture a point on a rotating wheel as it's moving, when that point crosses the highest position , think about how it's horizontal movement slowly starts to decrease, and when it reaches the position where it's lowest on the circle(half of a circle later), that horizontal velocity relative to the ground becomes zero for just a tiny moment, because at that moment that point is the point around which every other point on the circle is rotating around, and what is the definition of rotation? It's :
movement of an object in which at any given moment there is a point or a line of points(axis of rotation) which aren't moving!

If you still don't get it, just google "Cycloid" - that is the trajectory of a point on a circle as it is rotating, when you see it, you'll get what I'm talking about!

An open letter to those who complain about the content delivery:

Isn't it lucky that the information is being belied in a format where pausing, slowing down, and rewinding are all options? It isn't my intent to offend, but this video probably isn't exactly for you. That isn't to say crash course doesn't want as many people to enjoy their content as possible, but the original purpose was to be a resource for AP student. As someone who is currently in AP Physics and on this unit, this wasn't too fast. That's not to say that students are expected to catch everything just by watching it the first time through. But the students here are either watching it for a preview before class, an additional perspective, or a review before a test. No one is meant to walk away form crash course with a physics major. These are meant to be fast videos to give a basic understanding to curious internet goers and to help students learn and study.

Best wishes,
Vicki

This way you can watch the video and read associated caption for better understanding.

6:57 If the car is skidding over the ice, and the wheel isn't turning, but the bottom of the wheel is moving relative to the ground, this MUST mean that a) the car has a non-zero net translational velocity relative to the ice, and b) since the center of the wheel has the same translational velocity as the car, and the wheel isn't turning, the bottom of the wheel MUST have a NON-ZERO translational velocity relative to the ice. Meanwhile, in circle-strafing, you're increasing your transverse velocity, which is just the angular velocity of a larger circle. So you're maintaining a higher angular velocity with a larger circle, and outrunning your opponent, who has a slower angular velocity despite having a smaller radius to travel.

CrackCourse would be more appropriate. Honestly, how can you call this a course? If you had even the slightest awareness on how human beings absorb knowledge, is to plan pauses in your sentences strategically. Of course people could rewind stuff again and again, but that's not how the world works. The only people having a benefit out of this are those who are rehearsing for their exams, and those who just want to watch a witty video on a "sciency" topic so they can share the fraction of knowledge they've absorbed during the video to their even less educated friends. But a COURSE?`A course is about teaching. Rambling through all the information ASAP is not equivalent to that. It can be done fast and efficient, sure. But this is only fast. Not efficient.

I really admire the intent into these videos and a lot of them are good in my opinion. But personally, this one is an example of something that needs some more thought on how to actually efficiently convey information to the viewers.

Actually I found this video oversimplified, it treats the angular velocity like a scalar when it's a vector, same with the angular acceleration, and also, the rotation of a body cannot be described by a single angle because our space is in 3D, we need any of these things to describe it:
-Euler angles
-An angle and an axis(this can be described with a single vector that is the product of an unitarian vector by the angle)
-Quaternions
-A rotation matrix

Two mathematicians decide to have breakfast together. The waiter comes to their table and asks, "What would you like to eat?"
The first mathematician replied, "I'd like to have r pi."
So he got a full round pie which was twice the amount he asked and he was upset.
His colleague couldn't help but say, "Stop thinking in circles for one moment will you?"

Great video, packs in a lot of info and I'm sure many people will need to rewind sections many times to get it all.

One thing I found frustrating was I've never seen anyone treat angular motion from basics using tau instead of 2pi. While all the other references use 2pi, tau is a much more intuitive concept and one far easier for novices to grasp. Sure it's harder for those of us who are already familiar with the subject, but teachers should be making learning easier for their students, not themselves.

While I glean the gist of the video, I don't understand why the wheel has a bottom? It cannot be described by gravity, as the astronauts on the moon used the same physics as do the astronauts on the ISS as do we...  Ergo,  is the bottom of the wheel the point at maximum friction?  Or contact point? If that is true, then the contact point could be anywhere on the wheel and from that point all the other forces are calculated?

why did you make it so confusing.  You didn't bother to explain the concept of "relative velocity".  The reference frame makes all this wheel motion SO much easier to understand.  You made it 200% more complex by not discussing this concept.  The velocity of the wheel is ZERO relative to the ground because it's obviously not slipping, and relative to the center of the wheel it's obviously NOT zero.  It's like you didn't even try and make this easy to understand.  I'm glad I unsubscribed to this channel when this series started.  If the next one is better I will gladly resub.  But I love physics and this entire series sadly is a giant fail if you are actually trying to teach young people physics.  It saddens me.  It's too bad you filmed so many episodes prior to releasing them or you could've read your comments and corrected the problems.  Youtube is all about feedback.  When you produce and film like a television studio you fail to take advantage of the principle mantra of YouTube.  The VIEWERS drive the content.
